result.markdown: --- title: "\U0001F5FA Maps" subtitle: "Maps" author: "Arvind Venkatadri" date: "2023-01-12" weight : 70 summary: "Geospatial Data and how to use it with intent" tags: - Maps - Cartograms - Chloropleth Maps # - icon: flask # icon_pack: fas # name: lab # url: https://r-for-artists.netlify.app/labs/06-Grammar-of-Maps.html # # - icon: magic # icon_pack: fas # name: Introduction Slides # url: https://r-for-artists.netlify.app/slides/06-Spatial-Data-in-R.html --- {{< fa folder-open >}} Slides and Tutorials .nbsp;.nbsp; .nbsp;.nbsp; .nbsp;.nbsp; .nbsp;.nbsp; # Introduction First; let us watch a short, noisy video on maps: Maps That Will Change The Way You See The World:(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YH2sAbXv7p4) {{< youtube, YH2sAbXv7p4 >}} ## What kind of maps will we make? ### Chlorpleth ### Bubble Map ## A Workflow in Orange ## A Workflow in Radiant Radiant does not support map-making. We need to do it one of the many many ways available in R directly! ## A Workflow in R ### 1. Animal and Bird Migration 1. Head off to [movebank.org](https://www.movebank.org/cms/movebank-main) 2. Look at a few species of interest and choose one. 3. Download the data ( **ESRI Shapefile**) 4. Import that into R using `sf_read()` 5. See how you can plot locations, tracks and colour by species....based on the data you download. For tutorial info: ### 2. UFO Sightings Here is a UFO Sighting dataset, containing location and text descriptions.
